links.evidence: Dynamin‐related protein 1 (Drp1) is essential for fragmentation of mitochondria

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Numerous small and slim mitochondria and numerous long and thin mitochondria caused by the abnormal Drp1 or Mfn1, Mfn2, and OPA1 will lead to the insufficient supply of energy and overproduction of ROS in neurons, causing neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Increasing studies suggest that aberrant mitochondrial dynamics is one of the critical contributors of ALS, which is characterized by increased mitochondrial division and ROS production mediated by the hyperactivation of Drp1 causing bioenergetic failure and oxidative stress in the ALS finally leading to the degeneration of motor neurons.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: According to Kim et al.’s report, Siah2 (a ubiquitin ligase) can inhibit the expression of AKAP1 by decreasing the expression of protein kinase A (PKA) and FIS1–Drp1 interaction causing increased mitochondrial division finally leading to neural cell apoptosis.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In Ho et al.’s (2018) report, they found that increased kinase activity of LRRK2 due to the presence of the LRRK2 variant‐G2019S, which binds with and phosphorylates the Drp1 at T595 or s616 increasing its activity promoting the fission of mitochondria causing mitochondria‐derived apoptosis and production of ROS in the G2019S transgenic mouse brain, suggesting that the G2019S can lead to PD by affecting mitochondrial dynamics, increasing the fission of mitochondria.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Phosphorylation at Ser‐579 can increase the mitochondrial fission activity accelerating the cleavage of caspase- 3 leading to mouse cortical neurons apoptosis.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Nestin (a marker of neural system progenitor cells [NSPCs]) plays a pivotal role in the central nervous system (CNS) development and NSPCs stemness maintenance, and Wang et al. found that Nestin could sequester CDK5 in the cytosol then phosphorylate Drp1 at Ser‐592 leading to increased mitochondrial fission and glycolysis causing NSPCs differentiation and maintenance of its stemness (Jahani‐Asl et al., 2015; J. Wang et al., 2018).

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In a diabetic mouse model, GSK3β‐induced Drp1 phosphorylation at Ser‐616 involve in its synaptic deficits, and blockade of GSK3β by TDZD8 (an inhibitor of GSK3β) or inhibiting the fragmentation of mitochondria both tremendously improves mitochondrial and synaptic function.

links.evidence: Studies suggest that Drp1 can interact with some key pathogenic proteins‐Aβ, mutant PINK/Parkin, mutant Huntingtin (Htt), and mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) important in the pathogenesis of AD, PD, HD, and ALS, causing the dysfunction of mitochondrial dynamics in these diseases.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitogen‐activated protein kinase 1 (MAPK1) can cause over‐activation of Drp1 at Ser‐616 in HD knock-in mouse‐derived striatal cells which were found by Roe et al. causing mitochondria dysfunction finally leading to the occurrence of HD, and using U0126 (an inhibitor of MEK1/2) or Drp1 S616A (phosphorylation deficient mutant 1) canceled all of it (Chen et al., 2016; Chuang et al., 2016; Hyun, Min, & Kim, 2017; Jin et al., 2018; Kashatus et al., 2015; Xie et al., 2015).

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Here, in Roe and Qi’s (2018) paper, they show that the MAPK1 plays a critical role in the dysfunction of mitochondria and the neurodegeneration in HD by interaction with Drp1 and phosphorylates Drp1 at Ser‐616 causing the overactivation of the Drp1 finally leading to the aberrant mitochondrial dynamics in the HD knockin mouse‐derived striatal cells.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In Tang et al.’s report, they found that the treatment of oxygen glucose deprivation/ reperfusion (OGDR) in neuroblastoma Neuro 2a (N2a) mouse model can increase the number and activity of Drp1 and decrease the number and activity of Parkin confirming that the Drp1 knockdown or Parkin overexpression both play a protective role in neural system by decreasing the cell apoptosis and mitochondrial dysfunction.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In Tang et al.’s report, they found that the treatment of oxygen glucose deprivation/ reperfusion (OGDR) in neuroblastoma Neuro 2a (N2a) mouse model can increase the number and activity of Drp1 and decrease the number and activity of Parkin confirming that the Drp1 knockdown or Parkin overexpression both play a protective role in neural system by decreasing the cell apoptosis and mitochondrial dysfunction.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Drp1 has been implicated in various cellular changes in the pathogenesis of AD, such as the aberrations in the structure and function of mitochondria, the decreased number of synapses, and the increased inflammatory response.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Increased levels of S‐nitrosylated Drp1 was found by Haun et al. in the HD model of the mouse striatum and human postmortem brain from HD patients because of the abundant production of NO mediated by mutant Htt, causing the loss of dendritic spines and synaptic injuries, which can be reversed by inhibiting the region of S-nitrosylation on Drp1 through a non-nitrosylatable mutant Drp1 (C644A) and the inhibition of NO production by using nitric oxide inhibitors, suggesting that the S-nitrosylated Drp1 induced abnormal mitochondrial dynamics plays a crital role in the pathogenesis of HD.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The mitochondrial correlated ataxia is caused by the unbalanced mitochondrial dynamics, because of several reasons such as Purkinje neurons being one of the largest neurons in the CNS, they need a very high level of ATP through mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation following high production of ROS which harms the mitochondria itself, and the loss or dysregulation of mitophagy which is a critical pathway for the maintenance of healthy mitochondria through the clearance of damaged mitochondria by autophagy.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: More and more reports (Baek et al., 2017; Feng et al., 2018; Han et al., 2017; Joshi, Saw, Shamloo et al., 2018; Kandimalla, Manczak, Yin, Wang, & Reddy, 2018; Placido et al., 2017; Reddy et al., 2018; Reddy, Manczak, & Yin, 2017; Rui & Zheng, 2016) have shown that the Drp1 can interact with Aβ and the phosphorylated Tau, which are the two most reported pathogenic factors of AD causing excessive mitochondrial division, mitochondrial dynamics dysfuction, and synaptic degeneration leading to the dysregulation of the shape, size, distribution of mitochondria, and mitochondrial dynamics mediated axonal transport in AD neuronal cells.

links.evidence: In a diabetic mouse model, GSK3β‐induced Drp1 phosphorylation at Ser‐616 involve in its synaptic deficits, and blockade of GSK3β by TDZD8 (an inhibitor of GSK3β) or inhibiting the fragmentation of mitochondria both tremendously improves mitochondrial and synaptic function.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Mitogen‐activated protein kinase 1 (MAPK1) can cause over‐activation of Drp1 at Ser‐616 in HD knock-in mouse‐derived striatal cells which were found by Roe et al. causing mitochondria dysfunction finally leading to the occurrence of HD, and using U0126 (an inhibitor of MEK1/2) or Drp1 S616A (phosphorylation deficient mutant 1) canceled all of it (Chen et al., 2016; Chuang et al., 2016; Hyun, Min, & Kim, 2017; Jin et al., 2018; Kashatus et al., 2015; Xie et al., 2015).

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Here, in Roe and Qi’s (2018) paper, they show that the MAPK1 plays a critical role in the dysfunction of mitochondria and the neurodegeneration in HD by interaction with Drp1 and phosphorylates Drp1 at Ser‐616 causing the overactivation of the Drp1 finally leading to the aberrant mitochondrial dynamics in the HD knockin mouse‐derived striatal cells.

links.evidence: U0126, an inhibitor of MEK1/2, and Drp1 S616A, a Drp1 phosphorylation‐deficient mutant, both decrease the abnormal mitochondrial division seen in the HD, but U0126 cannot restore the impaired mitochondrial morphology, just reduce the level of depolarization in mitochondria and the production of reactive oxygen species in the striatal cells of HD mouse, which express the Drp1S616A compared with the wild‐type cells, suggesting the phosphorylated Drp1 at the downstream of MAPK1 pathway.

links.evidence: Drp1 partial KO mice are viable, fertile, of normal body size, and phenotypically have no obvious changes in mitochondrial proteins of synapses and dendrites, but remarkable reduction in the production of H2O2 and the level of lipid peroxidation compared with the WT mice, suggesting that Drp1 heterozygous KO can reduce excessive mitochondria division, maintain mitochondrial and synaptic function in neurons, and may become a novel research target for the treatment of AD or other neural system disorders.

links.evidence: In their work, they found that Drp1 interact with Aβ and hyperphosphorylated Tau which increased as AD progressed, decreased level of proteins important for the division of mitochondria (Drp1 and FIS1), increased level of proteins important for the fusion of mitochondria (Mfn1, Mfn2, and Opa1), the biogenesis of mitochondria (Nrf1, Nrf2, PGC1α, and TFAM), and the synaptic gene (synaptophysin and PSD95, etc.) by using immunoprecipitation and immunostaining analysis and these findings above can be ameliorated by the partial reduction of Drp1 leading to a decrease of Aβ and phosphorylated‐induced mitochondrial and synaptic toxicity finally maintaining the mitochondrial dynamics and neuronal function in the APPXDrp1 and TauXDrp1 heterozygote KO mouse.

links.evidence: Increased levels of S‐nitrosylated Drp1 was found by Haun et al. in the HD model of the mouse striatum and human postmortem brain from HD patients because of the abundant production of NO mediated by mutant Htt, causing the loss of dendritic spines and synaptic injuries, which can be reversed by inhibiting the region of S-nitrosylation on Drp1 through a non-nitrosylatable mutant Drp1 (C644A) and the inhibition of NO production by using nitric oxide inhibitors, suggesting that the S-nitrosylated Drp1 induced abnormal mitochondrial dynamics plays a crital role in the pathogenesis of HD.

links.evidence: The mitochondrial correlated ataxia is caused by the unbalanced mitochondrial dynamics, because of several reasons such as Purkinje neurons being one of the largest neurons in the CNS, they need a very high level of ATP through mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation following high production of ROS which harms the mitochondria itself, and the loss or dysregulation of mitophagy which is a critical pathway for the maintenance of healthy mitochondria through the clearance of damaged mitochondria by autophagy.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: More and more reports (Baek et al., 2017; Feng et al., 2018; Han et al., 2017; Joshi, Saw, Shamloo et al., 2018; Kandimalla, Manczak, Yin, Wang, & Reddy, 2018; Placido et al., 2017; Reddy et al., 2018; Reddy, Manczak, & Yin, 2017; Rui & Zheng, 2016) have shown that the Drp1 can interact with Aβ and the phosphorylated Tau, which are the two most reported pathogenic factors of AD causing excessive mitochondrial division, mitochondrial dynamics dysfuction, and synaptic degeneration leading to the dysregulation of the shape, size, distribution of mitochondria, and mitochondrial dynamics mediated axonal transport in AD neuronal cells.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In their work, they found that Drp1 interact with Aβ and hyperphosphorylated Tau which increased as AD progressed, decreased level of proteins important for the division of mitochondria (Drp1 and FIS1), increased level of proteins important for the fusion of mitochondria (Mfn1, Mfn2, and Opa1), the biogenesis of mitochondria (Nrf1, Nrf2, PGC1α, and TFAM), and the synaptic gene (synaptophysin and PSD95, etc.) by using immunoprecipitation and immunostaining analysis and these findings above can be ameliorated by the partial reduction of Drp1 leading to a decrease of Aβ and phosphorylated‐induced mitochondrial and synaptic toxicity finally maintaining the mitochondrial dynamics and neuronal function in the APPXDrp1 and TauXDrp1 heterozygote KO mouse.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Recent studies have demonstrated that the total reduction (homozygous knockout) of Drp1 in mice can cause some developmental abnormalities, such as decreased number of neurites and defective synapse formation due to aggregated mitochondria not distributing appropriately within cell processes, leading to abnormal development of the forebrain, indicating the critical role of mitochondrial division within the highly polarized neuronal cells.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Taken together, PINK1 can restore mitochondrial function and decrease the mitochondrial division induced by ischemia protecting the neuronal cells from the ischemic damage through inhibiting the transportation of Drp1 from cytosol to the mitochondria.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: It is reported by Zhao et al. (2013) that mutant PINK1 could cause collapsed mitochondrial dynamics, neuronal cell death, and the dysfunction of energy production, such as decreased ATP generation and impaired mitochondrial membrane potential through W437X and K219M (mutants of PINK1), or inhibiting PINK1 in the OGD neuronal model.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: The experiment by Shirendeb et al. verified the findings of Chen et al., they also found that the mutant Htt can interact with Drp1 enhancing the GTPase activity of Drp1 causing impaired axonal transportation, loss of synapses, and neuronal cell death in the postmortem HD patient brain specimen and in mutant Htt transgenic BACHD (a type of Huntinton's disease mouse model) mice developed by Gary et al, which can express the full‐length DNA (about 170 kb) of Htt.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: They also found that the abnormal interaction induced mitochondrial fission can also decrease the anterograde and retrograde axonal transport of mitochondria in synapses and cause neuronal cell death, which depends on the polyQ length, suggesting that the polyQ length determines disease onset and severity, thereby a longer expansion causes earlier onset of HD.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In their report, they found that mutant Htt can cause excessive production of NO which mediates the S‐nitrosylation of Drp1 increasing the division of mitochondrial and the loss synapses, deteriorating the neuronal damage in BACHD mice model cortical neurons as well as in postmortem HD patients’ brain specimens.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: In addition, they found that the S‐nitrosylation of Drp1 could promote the Drp1 interacting with the mutant Htt suggesting that the S‐nitrosylation function has an important role in promoting the Drp1 interacting with the mutant Htt and it is possible that the mutant Htt‐induced mitochondrial fragmentation and neuronal injury is mediated by SNO‐Drp1.

links.evidence: Here, in Roe and Qi’s (2018) paper, they show that the MAPK1 plays a critical role in the dysfunction of mitochondria and the neurodegeneration in HD by interaction with Drp1 and phosphorylates Drp1 at Ser‐616 causing the overactivation of the Drp1 finally leading to the aberrant mitochondrial dynamics in the HD knockin mouse‐derived striatal cells.

citation.name: Dynamin-related protein 1: A critical protein in the pathogenesis of neural system dysfunctions and neurodegenerative diseases.

links.evidence: Increasing studies suggest that aberrant mitochondrial dynamics is one of the critical contributors of ALS, which is characterized by increased mitochondrial division and ROS production mediated by the hyperactivation of Drp1 causing bioenergetic failure and oxidative stress in the ALS finally leading to the degeneration of motor neurons.

links.evidence: P110, a selective Drp1–FIS1 interaction inhibitor without affecting the basal mitochondrial fission, was found to improve the structure and function and significantly reduce the production of ROS causing increased neuronal cell viability and decreased muscle atrophy in SOD G93A mice suggesting that inhibition of the abnormal mitochondrial fission by the Drp1/FIS1 inhibitor ameliorate the disease progression of ALS.
